Award.AbstractNarration:
Industrial inspection, law enforcement, and museum preservation professionals all need to capture digital representations of real objects. These digital representations are later used for evidence and analysis that allows more efficient product manufacturing, faster criminal investigations, and preservation of priceless cultural objects. Existing cameras can capture a single view under a single lighting condition, and 3D scanners can capture the shape, but existing devices do not capture the surface reflectance properties.
In this proposal, the team has developed a method to capture photographs which allow the lighting to be interactively changed after they are captured. In addition, computation on the data can reveal details which are not visible to the naked eye.

A wide variety of sensors have been investigated in research labs and commercially. These include cameras that fundamentally measure light intensity, as well as depth sensors that fundamentally measure 3D object geometry. This proposal regards a related but different kind of sensor that fundamentally measures surface reflectance, how that surface reacts to light from different incident angles. This is important because the surface reflectance properties of an object may contain important information, even when the surface has no apparent detail when measured with a standard camera or depth sensor. In addition to surface reflectance, this new sensor can directly observe small changes in surface orientation which are below the noise threshold when measuring the surface shape with triangulation or time-of-flight based 3D depth sensors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major objective of this project was to determine the commercial viability of sensors for relightable images. The sensor had been developed as part of a prior NSF grant. The technology itself can be thought of as a “fancy flash” for a camera that allows the lighting in photographs to be changed after the image is taken. This sort of change cannot be accomplished using image editing tools alone, it requires a new device at the time of photograph capture.

We started this grant with knowledge that museum preservation departments and archeologists were really excited by the technology. The technology allows fine details in images to be seen and has been shown to be useful in revealing hidden details in everything from paintings to cuniform tablets. In order to bring the technology into wider use we wanted to investigate commercialization since museums are not a large enough market to sustain a company on their own. During this grant we interviewed hundreds of people in potential adjacent markets: photographers, tech enthusiasts, 3D printer companies, etc. Unfortunately we were not able to find a sufficiently large market for the relighting technology on its own. We did find continued interest from the known small market of museums and researchers. We delivered a half dozen samples of the technology to various groups, both as community service and to test the market sensitivity to price.

During the course of the grant we discovered that a number of users of 3D camera technology would be interested in having the fine details from the relighting technology added to existing methods of 3D capture. The team from this grant has now founded a new startup company and raised money  to investigate and commercialize this new idea. While this is not exactly the same technology or market, it is related, and is a positive outcome of the efforts under the grant.
